steps.title: Choose a matching or contrasting color yarn to use for a border.
steps.content: Choose a matching or contrasting color yarn to use for a border. You can add a border onto a knit or crocheted item that is the same color as the item or that is a different color. Consider how much you want the border to stand out and what color would work best with the item. [1] X Research source For example, if you will be adding a border onto a baby blue blanket, then you may choose a baby blue yarn in the same shade, or opt for something that will contrast with the blanket, such as pale yellow, mint green, or white.

steps.title: Pick yarn that is the same weight as the item.
steps.content: Pick yarn that is the same weight as the item. For best results, make sure that the yarn is the same weight as the yarn that was used to knit or crochet the item. You can find the yarn weight listed on the package of the yarn, or just compare a strand of the yarn in your item with a strand in the yarn you'd like to use and see if they are roughly the same diameter. [2] X Research source For example, if the item is made from medium-weight yarn, then use a medium-weight yarn for the border.

steps.title: Select a crochet hook that will work with the type of yarn you are using.
steps.content: Select a crochet hook that will work with the type of yarn you are using. Check your yarn’s label for a crochet hook size recommendation, or look it up online if you are unsure. Using the correct size hook for the yarn you have selected will help to ensure that you get the best results. [3] X Research source For example, if you are using a medium-weight yarn to create a scalloped border, then the recommended size may be a US size I-9 (5.5 mm).

steps.title: Slipstitch
steps.content: Slipstitch into the edge of the item. Identify where you want to work the first stitch on the border of your item. Then, make a slipknot and slide it onto your hook. Insert the end of the hook into the stitch where you want the border to begin. Then, loop the yarn over the end of the hook and pull it through both loops to anchor the yarn to your item. [4] X Research source If you plan to go all the way around the item, then you can start anywhere along the border. If you only plan to add a border to part of the item, decide where you want the border to begin and end.

steps.title: Chain
steps.content: Chain 1 to provide slack for the first stitch. Loop the yarn over the hook and pull this yarn through the loop to create 1 chain. [5] X Research source This will make it easier to work a scallop without making the item look puckered. [6] X Research source Repeat this before each new scallop.

steps.title: Skip 2 stitches and double crochet 5 times into the same stitch.
steps.content: Skip 2 stitches and double crochet 5 times into the same stitch. Do not work stitches into the first 2 stitches next to where you anchored the yarn. Go to the third stitch and then loop the yarn over the end of the hook 1 time. Insert the hook into the stitch, and yarn over again. Pull through 1, and then yarn over the hook again. Pull through 2, then yarn over again and pull through the last 2. [7] X Research source Repeat the double crochet stitch 4 more times into the same space. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Skip 2 stitches and slipstitch into the third stitch.
steps.content: Skip 2 stitches and slipstitch into the third stitch. After you complete the fifth double crochet stitch, skip the next 2 stitches. Then, work a slipstitch into the third stitch from where you worked the 5 double crochet stitches. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Repeat the sequence to continue adding scallops.
steps.content: Repeat the sequence to continue adding scallops. Chain 1, skip 2 stitches, and then double crochet 5 times into the third stitch. Then, skip 2 stitches and slipstitch into the third stitch. Repeat this sequence to keep adding scallops onto the edges of your project. [10] X Research source You can create as many scallops as you like using this sequence.

steps.title: Finish the border with a slipstitch.
steps.content: Finish the border with a slipstitch. Keep working until you have covered the desired section of your item. Then, work a slipstitch into the space between your first and last stitches if you are doing a full border, or after the last stitch if you are doing a partial border. [11] X Research source If you are doing a full border, do your best to position the last scallop and slipstitch so that the ends will be as evenly spaced as the rest of the item. However, don’t worry if you are 1 or 2 stitches off. It will not be noticeable.

steps.title: Cut the yarn 4 to 5 in (10 to 13 cm) from the last stitch.
steps.content: Cut the yarn 4 to 5 in (10 to 13 cm) from the last stitch. Use a sharp pair of scissors to cut the end of the yarn at this distance. It’s okay to estimate this length. It does not need to be exact. You just need enough yarn to easily pull the end through your last stitch. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Pull the end of the yarn through the loop on your crochet hook.
steps.content: Pull the end of the yarn through the loop on your crochet hook. Wrap the strand around the hook 1 time and then pull the end of the strand through the loop that is on the crochet hook. Bring the end of the strand all the way through the loop and tug the end until it is a tight knot. [13] X Research source This will secure the end of your border.

steps.title: Cut the loose ends 0.25 to 0.5 in (0.64 to 1.27 cm) from the border.
steps.content: Cut the loose ends 0.25 to 0.5 in (0.64 to 1.27 cm) from the border. You will have a tail at the beginning of your border and at the end of it. Cut each of these strands of yarn about 0.25 to 0.5 in (0.64 to 1.27 cm) from the last stitch. Do not cut the ends of your yarn any shorter than this or they may unravel. [14] X Research source Your border is complete after you cut the ends!
